summary: This is an email chain from August 19, 2019, concerning the investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's death at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. An MCC employee reports witnessing BOP (Bureau of Prisons) investigators shredding boxes of paperwork related to the Epstein suicide investigation, which the reporting employee believes is inappropriate. The emails discuss the urgency of checking a dumpster for the shredded material.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The investigation concerns his suicide while in custody at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York.

events.title: Shredding of investigation paperwork begins
events.description: An inmate at MCC NY was observed bringing bags of shredded papers to a dumpster, stating that members of the BOP after-action team investigating Epstein's suicide were shredding boxes of paperwork.

events.title: Continued shredding of paperwork
events.description: A second bag of shredded papers was brought to the dumpster, continuing the activity reported the previous day.

events.title: Email report of document destruction
events.description: An MCC employee sends an email reporting the observed shredding of investigation-related paperwork by the BOP team, prompting internal discussion about checking the dumpster for evidence.

locations: Rear gate area of MCC NY
keyFacts: An MCC employee reported that a BOP (Bureau of Prisons) 'after action team' investigating Jeffrey Epstein's suicide was shredding boxes of paperwork related to the investigation.
The shredding activity was observed on Thursday, August 15, 2019 (multiple bags) and Friday, August 16, 2019 (one bag).
The reporting employee stated the inmate involved was told to help shred the paperwork and quoted him as saying, 'they are shredding everything.'
The email chain shows urgent internal discussion about checking a dumpster to see if the shredded paper was still there, indicating concern over potential destruction of evidence.
The conduct was flagged as potentially inappropriate for an investigative team to be destroying records related to its own investigation.
